Hi David,

> You can install a new jar in your project's classpath, and remove the
> JUNIT_PATH element.

Yes, of course...
But the JUnit Lib in Eclipse is quite convenient.
As another workaround I can create my own user library in eclipse and use that instead.

> However, Kent and I were talking just Monday
> night about the fact that we end up coding on the latest version of
> JUnit, but supporting, mostly, whatever last shipped with Eclipse.  So
> suggestions on how to most easily enable Eclipse users to stay up to
> date are most welcome.

Wouldn't it be best, to manage the junit.jar-plugin correctly on the eclipse update site, so that the normal eclipse update-mechanisms distribute new junit versions.

This is probably more of an organisational problem.
Why not ask Erich Gamma about it?

Otherwise it may be an idea to supply a JUnit Update site for eclipse. But I don't know whether that collides with the installed plugin and how to resolve such a collision correctly.

Greetings,
   Malte
